29955996.review:
깜찍하고 아기자기한 숨은그림찾기 게임.

전부 손으로 그린 듯한 특유의 흑백 그림이 눈에 띈다. 그리고 그 그림들이 게임 화면 속에서 생동감 있게 움직인다. 하나하나 클릭하면 이리저리 꿈틀대거나 길어지거나 하는 등, 참 깨알같은 리액션을 보이기도 한다. 실사에 가까운 3D 그래픽이 판치는 이 시대에 한 편의 캐주얼한 웹툰을 보는 듯한 아기자기한 그림체가 매우 마음에 든다. 

게임에서 들려오는 생동감 넘치는 모든 효과음은 놀랍게도 사람이 직접 낸 소리다. 손으로 그린 그림이 움직인다는 것 만큼이나 상당한 감명을 받은 부분이다. 게임 하다보면 나도 모르게 무의식적으로 게임에서 들려오는 소리를 따라하게 된다. 특히나 트레일러 영상 끝부분에도 있었던, 악어의 흐으엉아아아~~~!!!! 가 매우 일품이다.

화면이 굉장히 넓다. 이걸 전부 손으로 그렸다는 것도 신기하긴 한데, 처음 화면을 맞닥뜨리게 되면 과연 이 드넓은 곳에서 찾아야 하는 걸 찾을수나 있을 지 걱정이 된다. 그래도 찾아야할 오브젝트를 아래에 띄워주고, 얼추 알만한 힌트도 던져주기 때문에 화면을 느긋이 보다보면 하나하나 발견해나가게 된다. 그리고 놀랍게도 이 힌트들이 전부 한국어로 번역되어 있는데 엄청난 초월번역을 자랑한다. 군데군데 유머러스한 부분도 아주 적절히 의역되어 있고, 한국인들이라면 익히 알만한 드립들도 적절히 들어가있다. 누군진 모르겠지만 번역하신 분, 복 받을거다.

게임을 플레이하다보면 한 편의 움직이는 웹툰을 보는 기분이 든다. 어딘가 아기자기자고 깜찍한게 보고 있자면 기분이 좋아진다. 다만 전부 수작업으로 그린 거라 그런지 스테이지가 조금 적은 편이다. 그래도 수시로 게임의 추가 컨텐츠가 업데이트 된다고 하니 그걸 기대해봐도 좋을 것 같다.

취향이 맞다면 매우 재밌게 즐길 수 있을 숨은그림찾기 게임!

http://blog.naver.com/kitpage/220936991620

29947025.review:
Hidden Folks is basically the video game version of an interactive Where's Waldo. 

The objective of the game is to find objects hidden in a scene. Hidden Folks is not your normal hidden object game though as in most levels you are looking through hundreds to thousands of objects. For each level you are given a number of objects that you need to find. A lot of these are out in the open but some of the objects require you to click or drag on other objects in order to reveal them. 

As a whole I would say that the game is moderately difficult if you want to 100% the game. In each level about half of the items are pretty easy to find, about 20-30% are moderately difficult and each level has 1-3 objects that are hard to find. While some of these hard to find objects would be frustrating to find, the game does have a good hint system that gives you a good enough clue to help you without leading you directly to the item. 

As far as the game's atmosphere, I would have to say that it is quite charming. The artwork is a little simplistic but charming at the same time. There is also the fact that all of the audio in the game was created by the developers themselves. 

The only really complaint I have for the game is that I wish it was a little longer. You could probably play through all of the levels in 2-4 hours if you don't care about finding all of the objects. If you want to 100% the game I would guess that it would take around 4-7 hours to complete. This is a decent length but I just wish there was a little more content in the game. 

Basically my recommendation comes down to whether the Where's Waldo premise appeals to you. If it doesn't it probably isn't worth picking up Hidden Folks. If you like these hidden object style games though I think you will really enjoy Hidden Folks.

If you would like to read my full review you can check it out on [url=http://www.geekyhobbies.com/hidden-folks-indie-game-review/] Geeky Hobbies[/url] .

Disclaimer: I know the developer and I contributed to the community translation

Hidden Folks is a cute little game with beautiful illustrations and really funny sound effects. The game is very playful and is perfect to play both alone or with friends. There are several levels and all of them are rich of details and feel alive: the player can click on almost every object in the attempt to find the specific targets, and this results in a very relaxed and playful experience. If you liked Where's Waldo and if you are looking for a laid back playful experience, Hidden Folks might be the right game.

29942474.review:
Hidden Folks is a relaxing, yet challenging, unique game and is guaranteed (by me) to have you laughing within the first minute of gameplay.  The developers have taken great care in making this game actually FUN and it shows throughout.  That's pretty rare these days.

The idea is simple: find hidden objects, some obscured by items like bushes, and move on to the next area.  There is a certain number per area that you need to find to move on to the next, but just go ahead and look for them ALL.  You're not a quitter, are you? I never did find that one chicken...

Anyway, there is a ton of of different things to interact with, even if it isn't one of the hidden objects.  The mouth-originated sound effects make it exciting to just click around and are way more addictive than I will publically admit.

With so many different games around that have cool trailers misleading you to think about all of the possibilities just to get a sale, Hidden Folks is simple and keeps it real.  Watch the trailer.  That's what you get... and it is entirely as fun as it looks!

10/10 would find folks again (DLC plz!)

39293565.review: [i]Hidden Folks[/i] is a really charming, entirely hand-drawn, 'hidden object' type game, very much in the style of the [i]Where's Wally[/i] books. The gameplay is largely based around searching for distinctive people and objects within a series of typically large and complex scenes, grouped according to themes such as snow, desert and forest - but the game remains compelling despite the apparently simple mechanics. Each scene features a lot of interactivity based around clicking on elements within it, from digging holes and parting trees/bushes, to operating switches with a variety of functions, to an extent far in excess of elements that relate directly to the target people/items - the care and attention lavished on the game is clearly evident throughout. The search for your targets is made more interesting by each being accompanied by a short text clue to their location, lending a puzzle-like feeling to many of them - while asmall handful of levels are actually full-blown puzzles rather than the usual people/object search. All told, a really great game.

39215235.review:
[b][u]EDIT- finished in 7.8 hours. Also- for those who are deaf or hearing Impaired... the audio in the game if fun and funny, but it is NOT neccessary to play this game. Very suitable for those who cannot hear, or cannot hear well.[/u][/b] 

[b][u]Overall Rating:[/u][/b] [b]9.5/10[/b]

Not a "classical" HOPA/HOG. 

This one is quite unique, a mix of "Where's Waldo" (obvious) with "West Of Loathing" (art style and humor).
A wonderful blend of the 2. 

Quite funny. The mouth-originated sounds are quite amusing, and a bit confusing at times, don't get distracted from solving a puzzle because you hear something "odd". You'll hear "odd" things a lot. And hopefully chuckle when you do. 

The Black-on-White line drawing art is very minimalist, and yes, it can be hard on the eyes after a bit. West Of Loathing has the same effect on my eyes, but thankfully, you do not need to play this for hours upon hours. It is quite good for short sessions, when you need to laugh, and relax a bit.  (The sepia tone background did not ease things for me, the White-On-Black was actually more difficult for my eyes to deal with. Your Mileage May Vary. Widely.)

The puzzles are clever. Some perhaps too clever, or intentionally vague. Some perhaps too easy. But there is a nice mix of "easy" and "hard" here. If it gets too frustrating, exit to menu, close the game, and come back later. The game saved perfectly for me, no resets on progress. And that allowed me to come back and rethink some puzzles, and solve them after looking at them in a new way. I like that. You can, and wil, find some things just by clicking randomly. But not all. The multi-step puzzles will make you think to solve them. I also like that. 

The screen can feel overly "busy" to me at times, but being able to zoom in using the muse wheel helps. Find an area that a clue seems to point to, zoom in, and take a closer look around. 

Replayability? Well, yes and no? I have gone back into some areas and played around after finishing them, just to interact with things or folks, just for giggles, and to see if anything I was not expecting happens. I haven't regretted it yet. And still have areas I want to back to, to click around and see what happens. And get a few more giggles. 

If you are thinking of buying just for quick achievements and Trading Cards... think again. neither comes fast. Card drops are about 1 hour apart for me, with the first dropping after 3 hours of playtime. I am fine with that. Traders/Sellers and Cheevo Hunters may not be. At the time of this review, I have 6.5 hours in, and 4/6 achievements., one more TC drop remaining. It isn't quick. quick should not be your reason for playing this. Relaxing, thinking, laughing, and [b]simple[/b] fun, should be.

Worth full price in my eyes, $1/hour or slightly less, by the time I 100% the game, is what I estimate. Get it on sale if you aren't sure. If you like playing casual games on your phone or tablet, it is available for a lower price on iTunes or in the GooglePlay Store. Not sure why they are priced differently as I look at them there now, not sure if one version is on sale or not. To be honest, I am not sure what this game would be like on a smaller screen. Having a 32" monitor made this less frustrating and taxing on my eyes. I don't think I could handle the smaller screen sizes well. But again, Your Mileage May Vary. Widely.

Enormi foreste, città con grattacieli altissimi, distese desertiche dove dietro al minimo dettaglio si cela qualcosa, un suono, un oggetto, un personaggio. Tutto è in movimento e molti degli elementi devono essere manipolati per trovare determinati punti della vostra lista che, per fortuna, non è necessario completare al 100% per poter proseguire, anche perchè i suggerimenti dati con ogni punto sembrano messi là per prenderci un pò in giro.

It's pretty much a Find waldo game where you have to find various people or things.

39473934.review:
Is there anyone alive who doesn’t love Where’s Waldo? I think not, ’cause you’d have to be pretty dead inside not to adore that goofy, stylish fellow and his equally eclectic friends. Where’s Waldo (or Wally, yes I am aware of the rest of the world) is a formative experience for a lot of children, mine included, and for good reason. His books provide hours of fun and occasional frustration as you pore over intricate scenes of beaches and ancient Egypt and movie sets and wherever else he ends up. Aside from a few antiquated attempts those enthralling adventures never made it to the gaming world, and no one really tried to emulate the experience. At least, not until now.

Hidden Folks is just that, a collection of folks hiding in scenes depicting cities and mountains and jungles and more. There’s no story to bother with here, just you and a whole bunch of folks to sift through until you find who you’re looking for. Each of the game’s two-dozen levels contains a number of folks, animals, or objects to locate amongst the many, many other things crowding them out. It’s not as simple as just skimming the scene either, because you can click on bushes and doors and signs to move things around and reveal particularly hidden folks. You can click on just about anything to get a reaction out of it, and honestly that’s like half the game’s appeal right there.

The novelty of an interactive picture search is definitely there but it’s the aesthetic that makes Hidden Folks truly shine. Everything in the game is hand-drawn in a modular style that allows buildings and people to be assembled from common parts into vast and varied arrangements. The style itself is charming as hell, using monochromatic lines to their fullest to produce entire worlds that look like clean textbook-margin doodles. It perfectly captures the dense wonder of a Waldo scene or a cartoony jigsaw puzzle, crammed full of little surprises to delight over. Though it never manages to be as varied as that which inspired it, thanks to the re-use of folks and buildings and decorations, there’s still plenty going on to keep your eyes busy.

In terms of mechanics, it’s really not all that different from a hidden object game. At the bottom of the screen is a row of people or things you need to find and click on. Scrolling through it pops up helpful hints that give you a vague idea of what the target’s surroundings are like. You could scan the entire level in search of each one, and you’d be rewarded with lots of precious scenes, but the clues generally guide you directly to the folk or thing you need to find. They’re all unique in appearance, and despite some tricky-sounding targets like tiny worms or golf balls I’ve never gotten stuck on one for more than a few minutes. You only need to find a few to move on to the next stage anyway, though I’m always compelled to catch ’em all before progressing.

There are five thematic areas, forest, desert, city, snow, and factory, each comprised of three to five levels. The first one is always tiny and gets you accustomed to the types of folks and moving parts you’ll encounter, and then the scenes get far larger from there. Early on you’ll be able to see pretty much the whole place by zooming out, but the desert and city have scenes that stretch on and on and on. These are the tricky ones, the ones where you can’l take the whole thing in and narrow down your search, and while they look neat they tend to slow the game down. Many of your targets aren’t out in the open, either, requiring you to click on holes or drag open blinds to find them. Again, it’s a neat bit of gameplay but slows the game down further.

In the end, Hidden Folks isn’t the interactive Where’s Waldo that some of us have been waiting decades for. The graphics are intensely charming but suffer from a lot of re-use and simplified animation. They never quite reach that same level of magic and wonder you get from those that inspired it, although the sound design makes up for a lot with all the effects produced by people making silly noises. My itch for seeking out hidden folks has been scratched here, and scratched for a good couple of hours. It could do better, it could do more, but there’s a beauty in its simplicity that sets it apart and helps it stand as a fine experience in its own right.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

39503183.review:
作品应该尽速推出清明上河图DLC。

[h1]黑夜给了我黑色眼睛，我却用它去游玩《Hidden Folks》[/h1]

这是一款有毒的游戏，它的核心目标非常简单，如同之前国内很火的一款游戏《找你妹》一样，你需要找到游戏中指定的人物、动植物或者其他物品等。游戏以全手绘风格呈现，所以初看上去简洁利落的画风非常吸引人，然而在通过简单的试练之后，你才会发现游戏画面就像是一袭华美的袍，爬满了虱子。而你要做的事情就是从这件迷人的性感长袍中找寻虱子。

黑夜给了我黑色眼睛，我却用它去游玩《Hidden Folks》，毫不客气地说，游戏是瞎眼利器。手绘风格导致游戏中的人物大同小异，你不得不一而再再而三地擦亮你的鹰眼去寻找他们，直到你看周围的物体都带重影，直到你看出“落了片白茫茫大地真干净”。游戏中需要找寻的对象却并非像是传统的《找你妹》一般直观呈现在图上，他们可能是移动着的，比如说在沙漠关卡，你就能遇到在飞毯上快速移动的阿拉丁。他们也可能需要互动，比如隐没在树林中，深埋在沙坑里，躲避在岩洞内，你可千万别以为简单互动就可以找到他们，事实上，游戏中充斥着各种相对于正确解谜而言不必要的互动干扰项，比如说你要找寻一个帐篷里的人物，你需要不断地掀开每一顶帐篷的门帘，从而才有可能发现你的目标。而这一切都是你需要克服的障碍，尽管游戏带有提示，不过提示往往只能限定一小片区域，而你如果要不自量力找到他们，往往是一个极尽痛苦的过程。再加上有些说明实在有些晦涩难懂，比如说沙漠关卡中的“眼镜蛇”的描述是：“伪装得太真实了，连自己都不知道自己在哪里”。小圆第一次玩到这里时，觉得这个眼镜蛇太诚恳了，连它自己都不知道自己在哪里，我又怎么会知道它在哪里呢？，又比如说“太空岩石”的说明是“你可以看得出这块石头是从太空上掉下来的”，是啊，真的是非常棒的说明，既然是叫太空岩石，我当然看得出它是从太空上掉下来的，不是吗？【1】

[h1]欢乐与痛苦[/h1]

既然如此，那为什么还要说《Hidden Folks》有毒呢？它带着对眼睛的恶意满满，为什么我们还要用我们的宝贵时间去不断重复乏味的试错过程？私以为，《Hidden Folks》的优点也恰巧体现在这个恶意中，如同孪生双子一般，快乐与痛苦如影随形。游戏目标简洁，其实创意来自Martin Handford的《Where's Waldo》系列书籍，你需要在众多形似的人物中找寻到Waldo，Waldo隐藏在一幅幅壮观的画卷中，栩栩如生的画卷充满了各种奇思妙想，《Hidden Folks》自然也是如此。《Hidden Folks》的整个画面是一出大故事，作品中从沙漠关卡开始，便会进入到一个异常巨大的全新世界中，你不得不到处移动你的鼠标来寻找目标究竟藏身何处。幸运的是，游戏有提示可用，提示是解谜的关键一环，它割裂了整个画卷，你可以快速锁定到一个小区域，而在这个小区域中上演着众生万象的小小舞台剧，你的目标便在附近。《Hidden Folks》的内容丰富，但却从未让我觉得画面拥挤不堪，而且是一副活动的画卷，在细节处又妙趣横生。比如以雪地关卡为例，我发现居然还有机器人也在滑雪，这实在是太有趣了！而且如同我前文所言，游戏的提示泛着一丝寒气，冷笑话感扑面而来。同样以雪地关卡为例，天才雪怪的描述是“喜欢宅居在家，远离尘世喧嚣，这样它才可以安静思考”。私以为，这不正是对游戏的目标玩家群体的概括吗？

游戏的另外一层快乐便来自于游戏的独家音效。“京中有善口技者”，游戏中超过960种音效通通来自Martin Kvale的口技。我喜欢互动来聆听游戏里各种各样的声音，这是解谜的另一环，它会告诉你地图暗藏杀机，比如沙漠关卡中躲起来怕被秃鹫袭击的人，比如雪地中遗失的人等等。我喜欢听他们发出“Help”的声音，每当我找到他们时，我的心里会不由自主变得温暖起来。我同时喜欢听找到目标时“Bling”的音效，毕竟身为女孩子，怎么会不喜欢"Bling~Bling~"的东西呢？

所以，尽管游戏带有恶意，但又充满着童稚的快乐。在你眼睛看累时，还是多出门走动走动吧~

[spoiler]评分：5/10[/spoiler]

39588223.review:
[h1][b]Encontré a Wally a la primera[/b][/h1]

[b]Así que eres de los que los libros de Wally (Waldo) se le quedaron pequeños y pensaba que no encontraría otra versión que no fuese la de papel para poder poner a prueba su paciencia y atención... O puede que esté suponiendo mal y simplemente te llamaron la atención esas estructuras en blanco y negro tan características del juego (a lo [i]West of Loathing[/i]).[/b]

[h1]Uff esto es muy difícil, yo paso[/h1]
La premisa del juego consiste en encontrar a unos personajes determinados que se repartirán a lo largo de las cuatro zonas principales de juego (con sus respectivos subniveles). Lo interesante es que, conforme vayamos avanzando y el juego nos vaya presentando sus nuevas mecánicas mediante las descripciones que nos da de los personajes, se irá rizando el rizo hasta el punto de que tengamos que interactuar con el entorno mediante un sistema de palancas, por ejemplo. Está muy bien integrado este detalle y es lo que hace que no nos dé la sensación de estar jugando a un simple port de [i]Buscando a Wally[/i] a PC. 

En cuanto a los personajes, veremos a muchos con aspecto similar a los que el juego nos pide y, de hecho, muchas veces nos quedaremos comparándolos diciendo: "PERO SI SON EXACTAMENTE IGUALES". Luego te das cuenta de que la descripción te dice que está enterrado bajo nieve y llega el momento [i]Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh[/i].

Mención especial a los sonidos del juego, los cuales son emitidos por onomatopeyas hechas por una persona con su propia boca, lo cual le añade un toque más pintoresco si cabe al juego.

[h1]No te quedes ciego[/h1]
Si el hecho de que el título se presente con un fondo totalmente blanco, pensando en que te va a deslumbrar por tus fotorreceptores ultrasensibles a la luz intensa, no te preocupes. El juego dispone de tres colores diferentes (blanco, negro y blanco con filtro rojo), aparte de una barrita que nos permitirá modificar el brillo a nuestro gusto.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
[i]Hidden Folks[/i] necesita una implementación de Workshop pronto si los desarrolladores quieren explotar el potencial del juego al 100%. De momento, merece la pena comprarlo ya que con el contenido de serie, tendremos juego para unas cuantas horas. Algunas fases llegan a ser largas (en torno a 1 hora, dependiendo del número de personajes se te encasquillen). 

Dicho esto, solo me queda añadir que me lo he pasado estupendamente jugándolo y que la zona de Nieve fue la que realmente me diagnosticó si tenía déficit de atención o no. Espero no tener que buscar más castillos de nieve, de verdad...
